definition:
Let $\alpha,\beta$ be ordinals. We define $\alpha^\beta$ as follows:
$$\alpha^\beta:= \left\{
\begin{array}{ll}
1 & \textrm{if }\beta=0,\\
\alpha^\gamma\cdot \alpha & \textrm{if $\beta$ is a successor ordinal and }\beta=S\gamma, \\
\sup\lbrace \alpha^\gamma \mid \gamma<\beta \rbrace & \textrm{if $\beta$ is a limit ordinal and }\beta=\sup\lbrace \gamma\mid \gamma<\beta\rbrace.
\end{array}
\right.$$

Some properties of exponentiation:

1.  $0^\alpha=0$ if $\alpha>0$

2.  $1^\alpha=1$

3.  $\alpha^1=\alpha$

4.  $\alpha^\beta\cdot \alpha^\gamma=\alpha^{\beta+\gamma}$

5.  $(\alpha^\beta)^\gamma=\alpha^{\beta\cdot\gamma}$

6.  For any ordinals $\alpha,\beta$ with $\alpha>0$ and $\beta>1$, there
    exists a unique triple $(\gamma,\delta,\epsilon)$ of ordinals such
    that $$\alpha=\beta^\gamma\cdot \delta+\epsilon$$ where
    $0<\delta<\beta$ and $\epsilon<\beta^\delta$.

All of these properties can be proved using transfinite induction.
